    Navigate to table in review
    Risk of bias for analysis 5.1 All‐cause mortality at up to day 28

    Bias

    Study

    Randomisation process

    Deviations from intended interventions

    Missing outcome data

    Measurement of the outcome

    Selection of the reported results

    Overall

    CoV‐Early

    This trial is a nationwide multicenter, double blind, randomized controlled trial in the Netherlands. Patients will be randomized between the transfusion of 300mL of convP versus regular fresh frozen plasma (FFP). However, there are not enough information avaiable yet on the allocation sequence concealement, as the full text article is not published yet and only the trial registry and requested data are available yet.

    Both participants and carers and people delivering the intervention were unaware of the assigned intervention received. There is no information available yet ony whether the analysis was appropriate.

    The trial registry does not provide enough information on missing data.

    Mortality is an objective outcome measure, appropriately measured and it is unlikely that the measurement differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were probably not aware of the intervention received.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the pre‐specified outcome in the trial registry.

    There are some concerns, as the data was provided on request and the study results are not published yet.

    Sullivan 2022

    Participants from all sites were randomized by a central web‐based system using blocked assignments to receive ABO compatible control plasma or CCP (both∼250 mL) in a 1:1 ratio.

    Participants were blinded, but and those delivering the intervention were aware of intervention received. However, there were no deviations from intended interventions and the analysis was appropriate.

    A modified intention‐to‐treat was used, so data for this outcome was available for nearly all participants randomized.

    The measurement of the outcome was appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were aware of the intervention received, but it is unlikely that knowledge of the intervention received could have affected outcome measurement.

    There was no information on whether the data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the predefined outcomes, as there is no protocol available and no information on mortality outcome provided in the trial registry. However, for this mortality outcome, the risk of bias remains still low.

    ‐
    Figures and Tables -
    Risk of bias for analysis 5.1 All‐cause mortality at up to day 28
    Navigate to table in review
    Risk of bias for analysis 5.2 Admission to hospital or death within 28 days

    Bias

    Study

    Randomisation process

    Deviations from intended interventions

    Missing outcome data

    Measurement of the outcome

    Selection of the reported results

    Overall

    CoV‐Early

    This trial is a nationwide multicenter, double blind, randomized controlled trial in the Netherlands. Patients will be randomized between the transfusion of 300mL of convP versus regular fresh frozen plasma (FFP). However, there are not enough information avaiable yet on the allocation sequence concealement, as the full text article is not published yet and only the trial registry and requested data are available yet.

    Both participants and carers and people delivering the intervention were unaware of the assigned intervention received. There is no information available yet ony whether the analysis was appropriate.

    The trial registry does not provide enough information on missing data.

    The trial registry does not provide enough information on the measurement of the outcome.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the pre‐specified outcome in the trial registry.

    There are some concerns, as the data was provided on request and the study results are not published yet.

    Sullivan 2022

    Participants from all sites were randomized by a central web‐based system using blocked assignments to receive ABO compatible control plasma or CCP (both∼250 mL) in a 1:1 ratio.

    Participants were blinded, but and those delivering the intervention were aware of intervention received. However, there were no deviations from intended interventions and the analysis was appropriate.

    A modified intention‐to‐treat was used, so data for this outcome was available for nearly all participants randomized.

    The measurement of the outcome was appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. COVID‐19 relatedness for hospitalizations was adjudicated by a three physician panel masked to treatment group.

    No protocol available, but the data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the predefined outcome in the trial registry.

    Low risk of bias in all the domains.
    Figures and Tables -
    Risk of bias for analysis 5.2 Admission to hospital or death within 28 days
    Navigate to table in review
    Risk of bias for analysis 5.3 All initial symptoms resolved (asymptomatic) at up to day 28

    Bias

    Study

    Randomisation process

    Deviations from intended interventions

    Missing outcome data

    Measurement of the outcome

    Selection of the reported results

    Overall

    CoV‐Early

    This trial is a nationwide multicenter, double blind, randomized controlled trial in the Netherlands. Patients will be randomized between the transfusion of 300mL of convP versus regular fresh frozen plasma (FFP). However, there are not enough information avaiable yet on the allocation sequence concealement, as the full text article is not published yet and only the trial registry and requested data are available yet.

    Both participants and carers and people delivering the intervention were unaware of the assigned intervention received. There is no information available yet ony whether the analysis was appropriate.

    The trial registry does not provide enough information on missing data.

    The trial registry does not provide enough information on missing data.

    The data was provided on request by the study investigators.

    There are some concerns, as the data was provided on request and the study results are not published yet.

    Figures and Tables -
    Risk of bias for analysis 5.3 All initial symptoms resolved (asymptomatic) at up to day 28
    Navigate to table in review
    Risk of bias for analysis 5.4 All initial symptoms resolved (asymptomatic) at up to day 14

    Bias

    Study

    Randomisation process

    Deviations from intended interventions

    Missing outcome data

    Measurement of the outcome

    Selection of the reported results

    Overall

    CoV‐Early

    This trial is a nationwide multicenter, double blind, randomized controlled trial in the Netherlands. Patients will be randomized between the transfusion of 300mL of convP versus regular fresh frozen plasma (FFP). However, there are not enough information avaiable yet on the allocation sequence concealement, as the full text article is not published yet and only the trial registry and requested data are available yet.

    Both participants and carers and people delivering the intervention were unaware of the assigned intervention received. There is no information available yet ony whether the analysis was appropriate.

    The trial registry does not provide enough information on missing data.

    The trial registry does not provide enough information on missing data.

    The data was provided on request by the study investigator.

    There are some concerns, as the data was provided on request and the study results are not published yet.

    Figures and Tables -
    Risk of bias for analysis 5.4 All initial symptoms resolved (asymptomatic) at up to day 14
    Navigate to table in review
    Risk of bias for analysis 5.5 Clinical worsening: need for hospitalisation with need of at least oxygen by mask or nasal prongs, or death

    Bias

    Study

    Randomisation process

    Deviations from intended interventions

    Missing outcome data

    Measurement of the outcome

    Selection of the reported results

    Overall

    Sullivan 2022

    Participants from all sites were randomized by a central web‐based system using blocked assignments to receive ABO compatible control plasma or CCP (both∼250 mL) in a 1:1 ratio.

    Participants were blinded, but and those delivering the intervention were aware of intervention received. However, there were no deviations from intended interventions and the analysis was appropriate.

    A modified intention‐to‐treat was used, so data for this outcome was available for nearly all participants randomized.

    The measurement of the outcome was appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. COVID‐19 relatedness for hospitalizations was adjudicated by a three physician panel masked to treatment group.

    There was no information on whether the data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the predefined outcomes, as there is no protocol available and no information on this outcome provided in the trial registry. However, for this this outcome, the risk of bias remains still low.

    Low risk of bias in all the domains.
    Figures and Tables -
    Risk of bias for analysis 5.5 Clinical worsening: need for hospitalisation with need of at least oxygen by mask or nasal prongs, or death
    Navigate to table in review
    Risk of bias for analysis 5.6 Clinical worsening: need for invasive mechanical ventilation or death at up to day 28

    Bias

    Study

    Randomisation process

    Deviations from intended interventions

    Missing outcome data

    Measurement of the outcome

    Selection of the reported results

    Overall

    CoV‐Early

    This trial is a nationwide multicenter, double blind, randomized controlled trial in the Netherlands. Patients will be randomized between the transfusion of 300mL of convP versus regular fresh frozen plasma (FFP). However, there are not enough information avaiable yet on the allocation sequence concealement, as the full text article is not published yet and only the trial registry and requested data are available yet.

    Both participants and carers and people delivering the intervention were unaware of the assigned intervention received. There is no information available yet ony whether the analysis was appropriate.

    The trial registry does not provide enough information on missing data.

    The trial registry does not provide enough information on missing data.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the pre‐specified outcome in the trial registry.

    There are some concerns, as the data was provided on request and the study results are not published yet.

    Figures and Tables -
    Risk of bias for analysis 5.6 Clinical worsening: need for invasive mechanical ventilation or death at up to day 28
    Navigate to table in review
    Risk of bias for analysis 6.1 All‐cause mortality at up to day 28 (random‐effects analysis)

    Bias

    Study

    Randomisation process

    Deviations from intended interventions

    Missing outcome data

    Measurement of the outcome

    Selection of the reported results

    Overall

    Subgroup 6.1.1 Antibodies detected at baseline

    Avendano‐Sola 2021

    Participants were randomized through a web‐based eCRF system (ORACLE clinical) in a 1:1 ratio to receive either convalescent plasma in addition to the standard therapy or standard of care alone and the allocation sequence was concealed. There are no baseline differences that would suggest a problem with randomisation.

    Both participants and those delivering the intervention were aware of intervention received, but there were no deviations from intended interventions and the analysis was appropriate.

    Data for this outcome was available for all the subgroup participants randomized.

    The measurement of the outcome was appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were aware of the intervention received, but it is unlikely that knowledge of intervention received could have affected outcome measurement.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the predefined outcomes stated in the trial registration.

    For the outcome "mortality at up to day 28", there is a low risk of bias for all the domains.

    Bar 2021

    Participants were assigned to treatment or control in a 1:1 ratio using randomization stratified on the use of remdesivir and mechanical ventilation at entry using block randomization with variable block size. There is no information on whether the allocation sequence was concealed.

    Both participants and those delivering the intervention were aware of intervention received, but there were no deviations from intended interventions and the analysis was appropriate.

    Data was awailable for all randomized participants for this subgroup.

    The measurement of the outcome was appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were aware of the intervention received.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the pre‐specified analysis plan and the outcome was reported as planned in the protocol.

    High because of first domain

    Estcourt 2021

    Participants were randomized via a centralized computer program to each intervention (available locally) starting with balanced assignment. The study will randomly allocate participants to one or more interventions, with each intervention nested within a domain. In this regard, a platform trial is no different to other forms of RCT in that randomization provides the basis for causal inference. However, unlike a conventional RCT, the proportion of participants who are randomized to each available intervention within a domain will not be fixed. Rather, the trial will incorporate RAR. RAR utilizes random allocation with a weighted probability for each intervention, with the weighted probability being proportional to the extent to which similar participants recruited earlier in the trial benefited or not from each particular intervention.

    Both participants and those delivering the intervention were aware of intervention received, but there were no deviations from intended interventions and the analysis was appropriate.

    Data for this outcome was available for (nearly) all participants randomized

    The measurement of the outcome was appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were aware of the intervention received, but it is unlikely that knowledge of intervention received could have affected outcome measurement.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the predefined outcomes stated in the trial protocol.

    ‐

    Horby 2021b

    Participants were randomized through web‐based simple randomization with allocation concealment in a 1:1:1 ratio to a platform trial in a factorial design, receiving either convalescent plasma in addition to the standard therapy or standard of care alone. There are no baseline differences that would suggest a problem with randomisation.

    Both participants and those delivering the intervention were aware of intervention received, but there were no deviations from intended interventions and the analysis was appropriate.

    Data was available for the randomized participants wihtin this subgroup.

    The measurement of the outcome was appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were probably not aware of the intervention received.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the pre‐specified analysis plan and the outcome was reported as planned in the protocol.

    For the outcome, there was a low risk of bias for all the domains.

    Ortigoza 2022

    A centralized electronic system was used to randomly assign enrolled patients to receive CCP or placebo in a 1:1 ratio stratified by enrollment site and risk status using randomization block sizes of 4 and 6 to maintain balanced group sizes. Allocation was concealed.

    Patients, treating clinicians, trial personnel, and outcome assessors were blinded to group assignment. ITT was used.

    Data for this outcome was available for all participants randomized.

    The measurement of the outcome was appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were not aware of the intervention received

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the pre‐specified analysis plan and the outcome was reported as planned in the protocol.

    ‐

    Subgroup 6.1.2 No antibodies detected at baseline

    Avendano‐Sola 2021

    Participants were randomized through a web‐based eCRF system (ORACLE clinical) in a 1:1 ratio to receive either convalescent plasma in addition to the standard therapy or standard of care alone and the allocation sequence was concealed. There are no baseline differences that would suggest a problem with randomisation.

    Both participants and those delivering the intervention were aware of intervention received, but there were no deviations from intended interventions and the analysis was appropriate.

    Data for this outcome was available for all the subgroup participants randomized.

    The measurement of the outcome was appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were aware of the intervention received, but it is unlikely that knowledge of intervention received could have affected outcome measurement.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the predefined outcomes stated in the trial registration.

    For the outcome "mortality at up to day 28", there is a low risk of bias for all the domains.

    Deviations from intended interventions

    Missing outcome data

    Measurement of the outcome

    Selection of the reported results

    Overall

    Subgroup 6.3.1 Antibodies detected at baseline

    Agarwal 2020

    The allocation sequence was random and concealed and there were no differences between intervention groups suggesting a problem with the randomization process.

    Five participants in convalescent plasma arm and four in control arm did not receive the allocated intervention. This could be due to awareness of the intervention, because this trial was open‐label.

    Data for this outcome was available for participants within this subgroup.

    The measurement of the outcome was appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. The data were collected in structured paper case record forms.

    The outcome was predefined in the trial reistry.

    ‐

    Horby 2021b

    Participants were randomized through web‐based simple randomization with allocation concealment in a 1:1:1 ratio to a platform trial in a factorial design, receiving either convalescent plasma in addition to the standard therapy or standard of care alone. There are no baseline differences that would suggest a problem with randomisation.

    Both participants and those delivering the intervention were aware of intervention received, but there were no deviations from intended interventions and the analysis was appropriate.

    Data for this outcome was available for all participants randomized.

    The measurement of the outcome was appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were probably not aware of the intervention received.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the pre‐specified analysis plan and the outcome was reported as planned in the protocol.

    Bias

    Study

    Randomisation process

    Deviations from intended interventions

    Missing outcome data

    Measurement of the outcome

    Selection of the reported results

    Overall

    Subgroup 7.1.1 Duration of symptom onset up to and including 7 days

    Gharbharan 2021

    Participants were randomized via a web‐based system in a 1:1 ratio to the current standard of care at each hospital with or without the addition of convalescent plasma. There are no baseline differences that would suggest a problem with randomisation.

    Both participants and those delivering the intervention were aware of intervention received, but there was no information on deviations from intended intervention, as insufficient information was provided on whether treatments were balanced across arms. The analysis was appropriate.

    Data for this outcome was available for all 86 participants randomized.

    The outcome assessors aware of the intervention received, but it is unlikely that knowledge of intervention received could have affected outcome measurement or that the measurement differed between intervention groups.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the pre‐specified analysis plan and the outcome was reported as planned in the protocol.

    ‐

    Horby 2021b

    Participants were randomized through web‐based simple randomization with allocation concealment in a 1:1:1 ratio to a platform trial in a factorial design, receiving either convalescent plasma in addition to the standard therapy or standard of care alone. There are no baseline differences that would suggest a problem with randomisation.

    Both participants and those delivering the intervention were aware of intervention received, but there were no deviations from intended interventions and the analysis was appropriate.

    Data for this outcome was available for the randomized participants within this subgroup.

    The measurement of the outcome was appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were probably not aware of the intervention received.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the pre‐specified analysis plan and the outcome was reported as planned in the protocol.

    For this outcome, there was a low risk of bias for all the domains.

    Korley 2021

    Baseline differences (characteristics are not balanced) in hospitalisation between groups suggesting a problem with randomization.

    The participants were blinded to the treatment, but those delivering the intervention were aware of intervention received. There were no deviations from intended interventions and the analysis was appropriate.

    Data for this outcome was available for (nearly) all participants randomized

    The measurement of the outcome was appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were unaware of the intervention received, so it is unlikely that knowledge of intervention received could have affected outcome measurement.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the predefined outcomes stated in the protocol.

    High risk of bias arising from the randomization process.

    Subgroup 7.1.2 Duration of symptom onset more than 7 days

    De Santis 2022

    The study methods it is stated that this is a "investigator‐initiated multicenter open‐label randomized controlled trial", but no further information on the allocation sequence concealment.

    Data for this outcome was available for (nearly) all participants randomized

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the predefined outcomes stated in the trial registration.

    ‐

    Subgroup 7.3.2 Duration of symptom onset more than 7 days

    Begin 2021

    Patients were randomised in a 2:1 ratio to receive convalescent plasma or standard of care using a secure, concealed, computer‐generated, web‐accessed randomization sequence (REDCap v11.0.1). Eligible patients were randomly assigned to receive either convalescent plasma or standard of care.

    articipants and those delivering the intervention were aware of intervention received. The trial was terminated at 78% of planned enrollment after meeting stopping criteria for futility, according to protocol, so there were no deviations from intended interventions and the analysis was appropriate.

    Data for all available

    The measurement of the outcome was appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the pre‐specified analysis plan and the outcome was reported as planned in the protocol.

    ‐

    Horby 2021b

    Participants were randomized through web‐based simple randomization with allocation concealment in a 1:1:1 ratio to a platform trial in a factorial design, receiving either convalescent plasma in addition to the standard therapy or standard of care alone. There are no baseline differences that would suggest a problem with randomisation.

    Both participants and those delivering the intervention were aware of intervention received, but there were no deviations from intended interventions and the analysis was appropriate.

    Data was available for randomized participants within this subgroup.

    The measurement of the outcome was appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were probably not aware of the intervention received.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the pre‐specified analysis plan and the outcome was reported as planned in the protocol.

    For the outcome, there was a low risk of bias for all the domains.

    Deviations from intended interventions

    Overall

    Subgroup 7.4.1 Duration of symptom onset up to 7 days

    Gharbharan 2021

    Participants were randomized via a web‐based system in a 1:1 ratio to the current standard of care at each hospital with or without the addition of convalescent plasma. There are no baseline differences that would suggest a problem with randomisation.

    Both participants and those delivering the intervention were aware of intervention received, but there was no information on deviations from intended intervention, as insufficient information was provided on whether treatments were balanced across arms. The analysis was appropriate.

    Data for this outcome was available for all 86 participants randomized.

    The outcome assessors aware of the intervention received, but it is unlikely that knowledge of intervention received could have affected outcome measurement or that the measurement differed between intervention groups.

    The data that produced this result was not a pre‐specified outcome from the registry.

    ‐

    Horby 2021b

    Participants were randomized through web‐based simple randomization with allocation concealment in a 1:1:1 ratio to a platform trial in a factorial design, receiving either convalescent plasma in addition to the standard therapy or standard of care alone. There are no baseline differences that would suggest a problem with randomisation.

    Both participants and those delivering the intervention were aware of intervention received, but there were no deviations from intended interventions and the analysis was appropriate.

    Data for this outcome was available for all 11,558 participants randomized.

    The measurement of the outcome was appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were probably not aware of the intervention received.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the pre‐specified analysis plan and the outcome was reported as planned in the protocol.

    ‐

    Subgroup 7.4.2 Duration of symptom onset more than 7 days

    Gharbharan 2021

    Participants were randomized via a web‐based system in a 1:1 ratio to the current standard of care at each hospital with or without the addition of convalescent plasma. There are no baseline differences that would suggest a problem with randomisation.

    Both participants and those delivering the intervention were aware of intervention received, but there was no information on deviations from intended intervention, as insufficient information was provided on whether treatments were balanced across arms. The analysis was appropriate.

    Data for this outcome was available for all 86 participants randomized.

    The outcome assessors aware of the intervention received, but it is unlikely that knowledge of intervention received could have affected outcome measurement or that the measurement differed between intervention groups.

    The data that produced this result was not a pre‐specified outcome from the registry.

    ‐

    Horby 2021b

    Participants were randomized through web‐based simple randomization with allocation concealment in a 1:1:1 ratio to a platform trial in a factorial design, receiving either convalescent plasma in addition to the standard therapy or standard of care alone. There are no baseline differences that would suggest a problem with randomisation.

    Both participants and those delivering the intervention were aware of intervention received, but there were no deviations from intended interventions and the analysis was appropriate.

    Data for this outcome was available for all 11,558 participants randomized.

    The measurement of the outcome was appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were probably not aware of the intervention received.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the pre‐specified analysis plan and the outcome was reported as planned in the protocol.

    ‐
    Figures and Tables -
    Risk of bias for analysis 7.4 Clinical improvement: participants discharged from hospital
    Navigate to table in review
    Risk of bias for analysis 8.1 All‐cause mortality at up to day 28 (random‐effects analysis)

    Bias

    Study

    Randomisation process

    Deviations from intended interventions

    Missing outcome data

    Measurement of the outcome

    Selection of the reported results

    Overall

    Subgroup 8.1.1 Duration of symptom onset up to and including 7 days

    O’Donnell 2021

    Participants were block randomized using a web‐based randomization platform in a 2:1 ratio to receive either convalescent plasma or standard plasma and the allocation sequence was concealed. There are no baseline differences that would suggest a problem with randomisation.

    Both participants and people delivering the intervention were unaware of the assigned intervention received and the analysis was appropriate.

    Data for this outcome was available for all 217 participants randomized, within this subrgoup.

    The measurement of the outcome was appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were unaware of the intervention received.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the predefined outcomes stated in the trial registration.

    For the outcome "28‐day mortality", there is a low risk of bias for all the domains.

    Subgroup 8.1.2 Duration of symptom onset more than 7 days

    O’Donnell 2021

    Participants were block randomized using a web‐based randomization platform in a 2:1 ratio to receive either convalescent plasma or standard plasma and the allocation sequence was concealed. There are no baseline differences that would suggest a problem with randomisation.

    Both participants and people delivering the intervention were unaware of the assigned intervention received and the analysis was appropriate.

    Data for this outcome was available for all 217 participants randomized, within this subrgoup.

    The measurement of the outcome was appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were unaware of the intervention received.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the predefined outcomes stated in the trial registration.

    For the outcome "28‐day mortality", there is a low risk of bias for all the domains.
    Figures and Tables -
    Risk of bias for analysis 8.1 All‐cause mortality at up to day 28 (random‐effects analysis)
    Navigate to table in review
    Risk of bias for analysis 9.1 All‐cause mortality at up to day 28

    Bias

    Study

    Randomisation process

    Deviations from intended interventions

    Missing outcome data

    Measurement of the outcome

    Selection of the reported results

    Overall

    Subgroup 9.1.1 Duration of symptom onset up to and including 7 days

    CoV‐Early

    This trial is a nationwide multicenter, double blind, randomized controlled trial in the Netherlands. Patients will be randomized between the transfusion of 300mL of convP versus regular fresh frozen plasma (FFP). However, there are not enough information avaiable yet on the allocation sequence concealement, as the full text article is not published yet and only the trial registry and requested data are available yet.

    Both participants and carers and people delivering the intervention were unaware of the assigned intervention received. There is no information available yet ony whether the analysis was appropriate.

    The trial registry does not provide enough information on missing data.

    Mortality is an objective outcome measure, appropriately measured and it is unlikely that the measurement differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were probably not aware of the intervention received.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the pre‐specified outcome in the trial registry. The subgroup data was provided on request by the study investigator.

    ‐

    Subgroup 9.1.2 Duration of symptom onset more than 7 days

    CoV‐Early

    This trial is a nationwide multicenter, double blind, randomized controlled trial in the Netherlands. Patients will be randomized between the transfusion of 300mL of convP versus regular fresh frozen plasma (FFP). However, there are not enough information avaiable yet on the allocation sequence concealement, as the full text article is not published yet and only the trial registry and requested data are available yet.

    Both participants and carers and people delivering the intervention were unaware of the assigned intervention received. There is no information available yet ony whether the analysis was appropriate.

    The trial registry does not provide enough information on missing data.

    Mortality is an objective outcome measure, appropriately measured and it is unlikely that the measurement differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were probably not aware of the intervention received.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the pre‐specified outcome in the trial registry. The subgroup data was provided on request by the study investigator.

    Subgroup 9.2.1 Duration of symptom onset up to and including 7 days

    Figures and Tables -
    Risk of bias for analysis 9.3 All initial symptoms resolved (asymptomatic) at up to day 28
    Navigate to table in review
    Risk of bias for analysis 10.1 All‐cause mortality at up to day 28 (random‐effects model)

    Bias

    Study

    Randomisation process

    Deviations from intended interventions

    Missing outcome data

    Measurement of the outcome

    Selection of the reported results

    Overall

    Subgroup 10.1.1 Immunosuppression (immune deficiency and cancer)

    Bar 2021

    Participants were assigned to treatment or control in a 1:1 ratio using randomization stratified on the use of remdesivir and mechanical ventilation at entry using block randomization with variable block size. There is no information on whether the allocation sequence was concealed.

    Both participants and those delivering the intervention were aware of intervention received, but there were no deviations from intended interventions and the analysis was appropriate.

    Data for this outcome was available for (nearly) all participants randomized

    The measurement of the outcome was appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were aware of the intervention received, but it is unlikely that the assessment of the outcome was influenced by knowledge of intervention received.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the predefined outcomes stated in the statistical analysis plan (SAP).

    ‐

    Estcourt 2021

    Participants were randomized via a centralized computer program to each intervention (available locally) starting with balanced assignment. The study will randomly allocate participants to one or more interventions, with each intervention nested within a domain. In this regard, a platform trial is no different to other forms of RCT in that randomization provides the basis for causal inference. However, unlike a conventional RCT, the proportion of participants who are randomized to each available intervention within a domain will not be fixed. Rather, the trial will incorporate RAR. RAR utilizes random allocation with a weighted probability for each intervention, with the weighted probability being proportional to the extent to which similar participants recruited earlier in the trial benefited or not from each particular intervention.

    Both participants and those delivering the intervention were aware of intervention received, but there were no deviations from intended interventions and the analysis was appropriate.

    Data for this outcome was available for (nearly) all participants randomized

    The measurement of the outcome was appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were aware of the intervention received, but it is unlikely that knowledge of intervention received could have affected outcome measurement.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the predefined outcomes stated in the trial protocol.

    ‐

    Gharbharan 2021

    Participants were randomized via a web‐based system in a 1:1 ratio to the current standard of care at each hospital with or without the addition of convalescent plasma. There are no baseline differences that would suggest a problem with randomisation.

    Both participants and those delivering the intervention were aware of intervention received, but there was no information on deviations from intended intervention, as insufficient information was provided on whether treatments were balanced across arms. The analysis was appropriate.

    Data for this outcome was available for all 86 participants randomized.

    The outcome assessors aware of the intervention received, but it is unlikely that knowledge of intervention received could have affected outcome measurement or that the measurement differed between intervention groups.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the pre‐specified analysis plan and the outcome was reported as planned in the protocol.

    ‐

    Subgroup 10.1.2 No immunosuppression (immune deficiency and cancer)

    CoV‐Early

    This trial is a nationwide multicenter, double blind, randomized controlled trial in the Netherlands. Patients will be randomized between the transfusion of 300mL of convP versus regular fresh frozen plasma (FFP).     The trial registry does not provide enough information on missing data.

    Subgroup 12.1.1 Diabetes

    Bar 2021

    Participants were assigned to treatment or control in a 1:1 ratio using randomization stratified on the use of remdesivir and mechanical ventilation at entry using block randomization with variable block size. There is no information on whether the allocation sequence was concealed.

    Figures and Tables -
    Risk of bias for analysis 12.1 All‐cause mortality at up to day 28
    Navigate to table in review
    Risk of bias for analysis 12.2 Clinical worsening: need for invasive mechanical ventilation or death

    Bias

    Study

    Randomisation process

    Deviations from intended interventions

    Missing outcome data

    Measurement of the outcome

    Selection of the reported results

    Overall

    Subgroup 12.2.1 Diabetes

    Begin 2021

    Patients were randomised in a 2:1 ratio to receive convalescent plasma or standard of care using a secure, concealed, computer‐generated, web‐accessed randomization sequence (REDCap v11.0.1). Eligible patients were randomly assigned to receive either convalescent plasma or standard of care.

    Participants and those delivering the intervention were aware of intervention received. The trial was terminated at 78% of planned enrollment after meeting stopping criteria for futility, according to protocol, so the interim analysis was no deviation from the protocol and the analysis was appropriate.

    Data were available for nearly all (921/938) participants. 17 Participants were lost to follow‐up at day 30 (after discharge).

    The measurement of the outcome was appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were aware of the intervention received, but it is unlikely that knowledge of intervention received could have affected outcome measurement.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the pre‐specified analysis plan and the outcome was reported as planned in the protocol.

    ‐

    Subgroup 12.2.2 No diabetes

    Begin 2021

    Patients were randomised in a 2:1 ratio to receive convalescent plasma or standard of care using a secure, concealed, computer‐generated, web‐accessed randomization sequence (REDCap v11.0.1). Eligible patients were randomly assigned to receive either convalescent plasma or standard of care.

    Participants and those delivering the intervention were aware of intervention received. The trial was terminated at 78% of planned enrollment after meeting stopping criteria for futility, according to protocol, so the interim analysis was no deviation from the protocol and the analysis was appropriate.

    Data were available for nearly all (921/938) participants. 17 Participants were lost to follow‐up at day 30 (after discharge).

    The measurement of the outcome was appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were aware of the intervention received, but it is unlikely that knowledge of intervention received could have affected outcome measurement.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the pre‐specified analysis plan and the outcome was reported as planned in the protocol.

    ‐

    Overall

    Subgroup 13.1.1 Diabetes

    CoV‐Early

    This trial is a nationwide multicenter, double blind, randomized controlled trial in the Netherlands. Patients will be randomized between the transfusion of 300mL of convP versus regular fresh frozen plasma (FFP). However, there are not enough information avaiable yet on the allocation sequence concealement, as the full text article is not published yet and only the trial registry and requested data are available yet.

    Both participants and carers and people delivering the intervention were unaware of the assigned intervention received. There is no information available yet ony whether the analysis was appropriate.

    The trial registry does not provide enough information on missing data.

    Mortality is an objective outcome measure, appropriately measured and it is unlikely that the measurement differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were probably not aware of the intervention received.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the pre‐specified outcome in the trial registry. The subgroup data was provided on request by the study investigator.

    ‐

    Subgroup 13.1.2 No diabetes

    CoV‐Early

    This trial is a nationwide multicenter, double blind, randomized controlled trial in the Netherlands. Patients will be randomized between the transfusion of 300mL of convP versus regular fresh frozen plasma (FFP). However, there are not enough information avaiable yet on the allocation sequence concealement, as the full text article is not published yet and only the trial registry and requested data are available yet.

    Both participants and carers and people delivering the intervention were unaware of the assigned intervention received. There is no information available yet ony whether the analysis was appropriate.

    The trial registry does not provide enough information on missing data.

    Mortality is an objective outcome measure, appropriately measured and it is unlikely that the measurement differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were probably not aware of the intervention received.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the pre‐specified outcome in the trial registry. The subgroup data was provided on request by the study investigator.

    ‐
    Figures and Tables -
    Risk of bias for analysis 13.1 All‐cause mortality at up to day 28
    Navigate to table in review
    Risk of bias for analysis 13.2 Admission to hospital or death within 28 days

    Bias

    Study

    Randomisation process

    Deviations from intended interventions

    Missing outcome data

    Measurement of the outcome

    Selection of the reported results

    Overall

    Subgroup 13.2.1 Diabetes

    CoV‐Early

    This trial is a nationwide multicenter, double blind, randomized controlled trial in the Netherlands. Patients will be randomized between the transfusion of 300mL of convP versus regular fresh frozen plasma (FFP). However, there are not enough information avaiable yet on the allocation sequence concealement, as the full text article is not published yet and only the trial registry and requested data are available yet.

    Both participants and carers and people delivering the intervention were unaware of the assigned intervention received. There is no information available yet ony whether the analysis was appropriate.

    The trial registry does not provide enough information on missing data.

    The trial registry does not provide enough information on the measurement of the outcome.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the pre‐specified outcome in the trial registry. The data was provided on request by the study investigators.

    ‐

    Sullivan 2022

    Participants from all sites were randomized by a central web‐based system using blocked assignments to receive ABO compatible control plasma or CCP (both∼250 mL) in a 1:1 ratio.

    Participants were blinded, but and those delivering the intervention were aware of intervention received. However, there were no deviations from intended interventions and the analysis was appropriate.

    A modified intention‐to‐treat was used, so data for this outcome was available for nearly all participants randomized.

    The measurement of the outcome was appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. COVID‐19 relatedness for hospitalizations was adjudicated by a three physician panel masked to treatment group.

    No protocol available, but the data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the predefined outcome in the trial registry.

    ‐

    Subgroup 13.2.2 No diabetes

    CoV‐Early

    This trial is a nationwide multicenter, double blind, randomized controlled trial in the Netherlands. Patients will be randomized between the transfusion of 300mL of convP versus regular fresh frozen plasma (FFP). However, there are not enough information avaiable yet on the allocation sequence concealement, as the full text article is not published yet and only the trial registry and requested data are available yet.

    Both participants and carers and people delivering the intervention were unaware of the assigned intervention received. There is no information available yet ony whether the analysis was appropriate.

    The trial registry does not provide enough information on missing data.

    The trial registry does not provide enough information on the measurement of the outcome.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the pre‐specified outcome in the trial registry. The data was provided on request by the study investigators.

    ‐

    Sullivan 2022

    Participants from all sites were randomized by a central web‐based system using blocked assignments to receive ABO compatible control plasma or CCP (both∼250 mL) in a 1:1 ratio.

    Participants were blinded, but and those delivering the intervention were aware of intervention received. However, there were no deviations from intended interventions and the analysis was appropriate.

    A modified intention‐to‐treat was used, so data for this outcome was available for nearly all participants randomized.

    The measurement of the outcome was appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. COVID‐19 relatedness for hospitalizations was adjudicated by a three physician panel masked to treatment group.

    No protocol available, but the data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the predefined outcome in the trial registry.

    Overall

    Subgroup 13.3.1 Diabetes

    CoV‐Early

    This trial is a nationwide multicenter, double blind, randomized controlled trial in the Netherlands. Patients will be randomized between the transfusion of 300mL of convP versus regular fresh frozen plasma (FFP). However, there are not enough information avaiable yet on the allocation sequence concealement, as the full text article is not published yet and only the trial registry and requested data are available yet.

    Both participants and carers and people delivering the intervention were unaware of the assigned intervention received. There is no information available yet ony whether the analysis was appropriate.

    The trial registry does not provide enough information on missing data.

    Mortality is an objective outcome measure, appropriately measured and it is unlikely that the measurement differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were probably not aware of the intervention received.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the pre‐specified outcome in the trial registry. The subgroup data was provided on request by the study investigator.

    ‐

    Subgroup 13.3.2 No diabetes

    CoV‐Early

    This trial is a nationwide multicenter, double blind, randomized controlled trial in the Netherlands. Patients will be randomized between the transfusion of 300mL of convP versus regular fresh frozen plasma (FFP). However, there are not enough information avaiable yet on the allocation sequence concealement, as the full text article is not published yet and only the trial registry and requested data are available yet.

    ‐
    Figures and Tables -
    Risk of bias for analysis 13.3 All initial symptoms resolved (asymptomatic) at up to day 28
    Navigate to table in review
    Risk of bias for analysis 14.1 All‐cause mortality at up to day 28

    Bias

    Study

    Randomisation process

    Deviations from intended interventions

    Missing outcome data

    Measurement of the outcome

    Selection of the reported results

    Overall

    Subgroup 14.1.1 Pulmonary disease

    Gharbharan 2021

    Participants were randomized via a web‐based system in a 1:1 ratio to the current standard of care at each hospital with or without the addition of convalescent plasma. There are no baseline differences that would suggest a problem with randomisation.

    Both participants and those delivering the intervention were aware of intervention received, but there was no information on deviations from intended intervention, as insufficient information was provided on whether treatments were balanced across arms. The analysis was appropriate.

    Data for this outcome was available for all 86 participants randomized.

    The outcome assessors aware of the intervention received, but it is unlikely that knowledge of intervention received could have affected outcome measurement or that the measurement differed between intervention groups.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the pre‐specified analysis plan and the outcome was reported as planned in the protocol.

    ‐

    Subgroup 14.1.2 No pulmonary disease

    Gharbharan 2021

    Participants were randomized via a web‐based system in a 1:1 ratio to the current standard of care at each hospital with or without the addition of convalescent plasma. There are no baseline differences that would suggest a problem with randomisation.

    Both participants and those delivering the intervention were aware of intervention received, but there was no information on deviations from intended intervention, as insufficient information was provided on whether treatments were balanced across arms. The analysis was appropriate.

    Data for this outcome was available for all 86 participants randomized.

    The outcome assessors aware of the intervention received, but it is unlikely that knowledge of intervention received could have affected outcome measurement or that the measurement differed between intervention groups.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the pre‐specified analysis plan and the outcome was reported as planned in the protocol.

    ‐
    Figures and Tables -
    Risk of bias for analysis 14.1 All‐cause mortality at up to day 28
    Navigate to table in review
    Risk of bias for analysis 14.2 Clinical worsening: need for invasive mechanical ventilation or death

    Bias

    Study

    Randomisation process

    Deviations from intended interventions

    Missing outcome data

    Measurement of the outcome

    Selection of the reported results

    Overall

    Subgroup 14.2.1 Respiratory disease

    Begin 2021

    Patients were randomised in a 2:1 ratio to receive convalescent plasma or standard of care using a secure, concealed, computer‐generated, web‐accessed randomization sequence (REDCap v11.0.1). Eligible patients were randomly assigned to receive either convalescent plasma or standard of care.

    Participants and those delivering the intervention were aware of intervention received. The trial was terminated at 78% of planned enrollment after meeting stopping criteria for futility, according to protocol, so the interim analysis was no deviation from the protocol and the analysis was appropriate.

    Data were available for nearly all (921/938) participants. 17 Participants were lost to follow‐up at day 30 (after discharge).

    The measurement of the outcome was appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were aware of the intervention received, but it is unlikely that knowledge of intervention received could have affected outcome measurement.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the pre‐specified analysis plan and the outcome was reported as planned in the protocol.

    ‐

    Subgroup 14.2.2 No respiratory disease

    Begin 2021

    Patients were randomised in a 2:1 ratio to receive convalescent plasma or standard of care using a secure, concealed, computer‐generated, web‐accessed randomization sequence (REDCap v11.0.1). Eligible patients were randomly assigned to receive either convalescent plasma or standard of care.

    Participants and those delivering the intervention were aware of intervention received. The trial was terminated at 78% of planned enrollment after meeting stopping criteria for futility, according to protocol, so the interim analysis was no deviation from the protocol and the analysis was appropriate.

    Data were available for nearly all (921/938) participants. 17 Participants were lost to follow‐up at day 30 (after discharge).

    The measurement of the outcome was appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were aware of the intervention received, but it is unlikely that knowledge of intervention received could have affected outcome measurement.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the pre‐specified analysis plan and the outcome was reported as planned in the protocol.

    ‐
    Figures and Tables -
    Risk of bias for analysis 14.2 Clinical worsening: need for invasive mechanical ventilation or death
    Navigate to table in review
    Risk of bias for analysis 14.3 Clinical improvement: participants discharged from hospital

    Bias

    Study

    Randomisation process

    Deviations from intended interventions

    Missing outcome data

    Measurement of the outcome

    Selection of the reported results

    Overall

    Subgroup 14.3.1 Pulmonary disease

    Gharbharan 2021

    Participants were randomized via a web‐based system in a 1:1 ratio to the current standard of care at each hospital with or without the addition of convalescent plasma. There are no baseline differences that would suggest a problem with randomisation.

    Both participants and those delivering the intervention were aware of intervention received, but there was no information on deviations from intended intervention, as insufficient information was provided on whether treatments were balanced across arms. The analysis was appropriate.

    Data for this outcome was available for all 86 participants randomized.

    The outcome assessors aware of the intervention received, but it is unlikely that knowledge of intervention received could have affected outcome measurement or that the measurement differed between intervention groups.

    The data that produced this result was not a pre‐specified outcome from the registry.

    ‐

    Subgroup 14.3.2 No pulmonary disease

    Gharbharan 2021

    Figures and Tables -
    Risk of bias for analysis 14.3 Clinical improvement: participants discharged from hospital
    Navigate to table in review
    Risk of bias for analysis 15.1 All‐cause mortality at up to day 28

    Bias

    Study

    Randomisation process

    Deviations from intended interventions

    Missing outcome data

    Measurement of the outcome

    Selection of the reported results

    Overall

    Subgroup 15.1.1 Hypertension

    Bar 2021

    Participants were assigned to treatment or control in a 1:1 ratio using randomization stratified on the use of remdesivir and mechanical ventilation at entry using block randomization with variable block size. There is no information on whether the allocation sequence was concealed.

    Both participants and those delivering the intervention were aware of intervention received, but there were no deviations from intended interventions and the analysis was appropriate.

    Data for this outcome was available for (nearly) all participants randomized

    The measurement of the outcome was appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were aware of the intervention received, but it is unlikely that the assessment of the outcome was influenced by knowledge of intervention received.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the predefined outcomes stated in the statistical analysis plan (SAP).

    ‐

    Gharbharan 2021

    Participants were randomized via a web‐based system in a 1:1 ratio to the current standard of care at each hospital with or without the addition of convalescent plasma. There are no baseline differences that would suggest a problem with randomisation.

    Both participants and those delivering the intervention were aware of intervention received, but there was no information on deviations from intended intervention, as insufficient information was provided on whether treatments were balanced across arms. The analysis was appropriate.

    Data for this outcome was available for all 86 participants randomized.

    The outcome assessors aware of the intervention received, but it is unlikely that knowledge of intervention received could have affected outcome measurement or that the measurement differed between intervention groups.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the pre‐specified analysis plan and the outcome was reported as planned in the protocol.

    ‐

    Overall

    Subgroup 16.2.1 < 60 years

    Begin 2021

    Patients were randomised in a 2:1 ratio to receive convalescent plasma or standard of care using a secure, concealed, computer‐generated, web‐accessed randomization sequence (REDCap v11.0.1). Eligible patients were randomly assigned to receive either convalescent plasma or standard of care.

    Participants and those delivering the intervention were aware of intervention received. The trial was terminated at 78% of planned enrollment after meeting stopping criteria for futility, according to protocol, so the interim analysis was no deviation from the protocol and the analysis was appropriate.

    Data were available for nearly all (921/938) participants. 17 Participants were lost to follow‐up at day 30 (after discharge).

    The measurement of the outcome was appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were aware of the intervention received, but it is unlikely that knowledge of intervention received could have affected outcome measurement.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the pre‐specified analysis plan and the outcome was reported as planned in the protocol.

    ‐

    Subgroup 16.2.2 ≥ 60 years

    Begin 2021

    Patients were randomised in a 2:1 ratio to receive convalescent plasma or standard of care using a secure, concealed, computer‐generated, web‐accessed randomization sequence (REDCap v11.0.1). Eligible patients were randomly assigned to receive either convalescent plasma or standard of care.

    Participants and those delivering the intervention were aware of intervention received. The trial was terminated at 78% of planned enrollment after meeting stopping criteria for futility, according to protocol, so the interim analysis was no deviation from the protocol and the analysis was appropriate.

    Data were available for nearly all (921/938) participants. 17 Participants were lost to follow‐up at day 30 (after discharge).

    The measurement of the outcome was appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were aware of the intervention received, but it is unlikely that knowledge of intervention received could have affected outcome measurement.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the pre‐specified analysis plan and the outcome was reported as planned in the protocol.

    ‐

    Subgroup 16.2.3 < 70 years

    Horby 2021b

    Participants were randomized through web‐based simple randomization with allocation concealment in a 1:1:1 ratio to a platform trial in a factorial design, receiving either convalescent plasma in addition to the standard therapy or standard of care alone. There are no baseline differences that would suggest a problem with randomisation.

    Both participants and those delivering the intervention were aware of intervention received, but there were no deviations from intended interventions and the analysis was appropriate.

    Data for this outcome was available for all participants randomized.

    The measurement of the outcome was appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were probably not aware of the intervention received.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the pre‐specified analysis plan and the outcome was reported as planned in the protocol.

    ‐

    Subgroup 16.2.4 ≥ 70 years

    Horby 2021b

    Participants were randomized through web‐based simple randomization with allocation concealment in a 1:1:1 ratio to a platform trial in a factorial design, receiving either convalescent plasma in addition to the standard therapy or standard of care alone. There are no baseline differences that would suggest a problem with randomisation.

    Both participants and those delivering the intervention were aware of intervention received, but there were no deviations from intended interventions and the analysis was appropriate.

    Data for this outcome was available for all participants randomized.

    The measurement of the outcome was appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were probably not aware of the intervention received.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the pre‐specified analysis plan and the outcome was reported as planned in the protocol.

There are no baseline differences that would suggest a problem with randomisation.

    Both participants and those delivering the intervention were aware of intervention received, but there were no deviations from intended interventions and the analysis was appropriate.

    Data for this outcome was available for all 11,558 participants randomized.

    The measurement of the outcome was appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were probably not aware of the intervention received.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the pre‐specified analysis plan and the outcome was reported as planned in the protocol.

    Risk of bias for analysis 17.1 All‐cause mortality at up to day 28

    Bias

    Study

    Randomisation process

    Deviations from intended interventions

    Missing outcome data

    Measurement of the outcome

    Selection of the reported results

    Overall

    Subgroup 17.1.1 < 65 years

    CoV‐Early

    This trial is a nationwide multicenter, double blind, randomized controlled trial in the Netherlands. Patients will be randomized between the transfusion of 300mL of convP versus regular fresh frozen plasma (FFP). However, there are not enough information avaiable yet on the allocation sequence concealement, as the full text article is not published yet and only the trial registry and requested data are available yet.

    Both participants and carers and people delivering the intervention were unaware of the assigned intervention received. There is no information available yet ony whether the analysis was appropriate.

    The trial registry does not provide enough information on missing data.

    Mortality is an objective outcome measure, appropriately measured and it is unlikely that the measurement differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were probably not aware of the intervention received.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the pre‐specified outcome in the trial registry. The subgroup data was provided on request by the study investigator.

    ‐

    Subgroup 17.1.2 ≥ 65 years

    CoV‐Early

    This trial is a nationwide multicenter, double blind, randomized controlled trial in the Netherlands. Patients will be randomized between the transfusion of 300mL of convP versus regular fresh frozen plasma (FFP). However, there are not enough information avaiable yet on the allocation sequence concealement, as the full text article is not published yet and only the trial registry and requested data are available yet.

    Both participants and carers and people delivering the intervention were unaware of the assigned intervention received. There is no information available yet ony whether the analysis was appropriate.

    The trial registry does not provide enough information on missing data.

    Mortality is an objective outcome measure, appropriately measured and it is unlikely that the measurement differed between intervention groups. The outcome assessors were probably not aware of the intervention received.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the pre‐specified outcome in the trial registry. The subgroup data was provided on request by the study investigator.

    ‐
    Figures and Tables -
    Risk of bias for analysis 17.1 All‐cause mortality at up to day 28
    Navigate to table in review
    Risk of bias for analysis 17.2 Admission to hospital or death within 28 days

    Bias

    Study

    Randomisation process

    Deviations from intended interventions

    Missing outcome data

    Measurement of the outcome

    Selection of the reported results

    Overall

    Subgroup 17.2.1 < 65 years

    CoV‐Early

    This trial is a nationwide multicenter, double blind, randomized controlled trial in the Netherlands. Patients will be randomized between the transfusion of 300mL of convP versus regular fresh frozen plasma (FFP). However, there are not enough information avaiable yet on the allocation sequence concealement, as the full text article is not published yet and only the trial registry and requested data are available yet.

    Both participants and carers and people delivering the intervention were unaware of the assigned intervention received. There is no information available yet ony whether the analysis was appropriate.

    The trial registry does not provide enough information on missing data.

    The trial registry does not provide enough information on the measurement of the outcome.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the pre‐specified outcome in the trial registry. The data was provided on request by the study investigators.

    ‐

    Sullivan 2022

    Participants from all sites were randomized by a central web‐based system using blocked assignments to receive ABO compatible control plasma or CCP (both∼250 mL) in a 1:1 ratio.

    Participants were blinded, but and those delivering the intervention were aware of intervention received. However, there were no deviations from intended interventions and the analysis was appropriate.

    A modified intention‐to‐treat was used, so data for this outcome was available for nearly all participants randomized.

    The measurement of the outcome was appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. COVID‐19 relatedness for hospitalizations was adjudicated by a three physician panel masked to treatment group.

    No protocol available, but the data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the predefined outcome in the trial registry.

    ‐

    Subgroup 17.2.2 ≥ 65 years

    CoV‐Early

    This trial is a nationwide multicenter, double blind, randomized controlled trial in the Netherlands. Patients will be randomized between the transfusion of 300mL of convP versus regular fresh frozen plasma (FFP). However, there are not enough information avaiable yet on the allocation sequence concealement, as the full text article is not published yet and only the trial registry and requested data are available yet.

    Both participants and carers and people delivering the intervention were unaware of the assigned intervention received. There is no information available yet ony whether the analysis was appropriate.

    The trial registry does not provide enough information on missing data.

    The trial registry does not provide enough information on the measurement of the outcome.

    The data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the pre‐specified outcome in the trial registry. The data was provided on request by the study investigators.

    ‐

    Sullivan 2022

    Participants from all sites were randomized by a central web‐based system using blocked assignments to receive ABO compatible control plasma or CCP (both∼250 mL) in a 1:1 ratio.

    Participants were blinded, but and those delivering the intervention were aware of intervention received. However, there were no deviations from intended interventions and the analysis was appropriate.

    A modified intention‐to‐treat was used, so data for this outcome was available for nearly all participants randomized.

    The measurement of the outcome was appropriate and it is unlikely that it differed between intervention groups. COVID‐19 relatedness for hospitalizations was adjudicated by a three physician panel masked to treatment group.

    No protocol available, but the data that produced this result was analysed in accordance with the predefined outcome in the trial registry.
